comment.author: 8214568@N08
comment._content: Street View The Church of Ss Peter & Paul was designed by Edward Pugin. The foundation stone was laid 15 Aug 1859. It seems to have been finished about 1861, although it wasn’t dedicated until 29 Jun 1866.

comment.author: 30687643@N00
comment._content: St Peter and St. Pauls church is much the same today tho the archway has gone. The road leads up to Paul St and shopping centre maps.google.co.uk/maps?q=st+patricks+st+cork&hl=en&am...

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: If you follow Google Street View as provided by Gerry Ward you can see that there is a sign that it is St. Peter and Pauls church and that the "Mass" times are displayed so it is an RC and none of non-comformist stuff:-))

comment.author: 30687643@N00
comment._content: the steps up the side of the building are a relic of the time when Patrick St was a waterway and prone to flooding . Le chateau bar still has steps to the first floor maps.google.co.uk/maps?q=st+patricks+st+cork&hl=en&am...

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: It was the second church built on that site and so the reference to the "new" church may have been to this building.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/gerryward] Thanks Gerry, for map location (not half so attractive looking, or am I biased?) and for the dating information on the church... So definitely after 1861, as the church looks fully finished. "Dedication" is not quite so externally obvious.

So now we're 1861-1883!

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: In the 1863 Laing's directory, Guys is at #74, so this is after 1863. In the 1870 Slaters Guy's is at #70, and Allen is at #69, and Martin Russell (baker) is at #71, so that all looks perfect. 1871 Fultons, ditto, 1875, Guys, same again, 1881 Slaters, more of, In the 1884 Guy's, Martin Russell is gone! Not much help narrowing it down, just bumps the earliest year possible to 1863.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: 1867 Henry & Coughlan: Allen #69, Guy #70, Russell #71, no help.

comment.author: 37424391@N07
comment._content: Respect,.,!!

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: Wayhay! A Cork one boy :) This is a veritable treasure trove from my POV. I am late to the party as usual, but here's my notes: Date: I can't add more than Niall and Gerry. I expect this is between 1865(ish) and 1875(ish). ADDRESSES: #70: Is of significant importance to Cork history nerds as (as has been noted) it's the home of Guy's almanac printers. (See contemporary print ad). The Cork City Library also has other smashing sources on Guy's. Including a great (granted commercially biased) text that confirms that Guy's premises stretched all the way back to Paul St:   T h e buildings occupied by the business as a whole run from Patrick-street to Paul-street, and have a frontage the entire length of the way in S S . Peter and Paul's Place. T h e value of such a commodious location cannot be over-estimated, particularly in the handling of heavy goods. Instead of having only the common door for entrance and exit, every department has a special means of communication with the street, and to a great extent is independent of that which adjoins it—an arrangement of no .light importance in the case of fire. #69: Was indeed Allen's drapery and tailors shop. A location it occupied through to the 20th century. (My own grandmother set-up her ladies tailoring business in a rented space on the other side of the street. In Burton's buildings. Above Gerald Goldberg's legal offices) CHURCH: St Peter and Paul's is indeed RC, and also notable to history nerds as being a good genealogical records source. (As well as being a good "living history" spot given it's "pre Vatican II" Latin masses).

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: Another very interesting photo. I found this nice family history on Francis Guy and his wife Mary Ann Canter, Francis Guy & Mary Anne Canter Guys were also photographers, this is one of theirs from around 1917/18

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Hurrah, Mr. Guy married a Limerick woman in the "sinking church" St. Michaels C of I in Pery's Square which featured here some time ago.  His brother also married a sister of the first bride so the links are strong between the two cities.

comment.author: 59941010@N06
comment._content: Great image of St's Peter & Paul's Church. I like the couple in the doorway :)

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: Upstairs from the Francis Guy establishment seems to be a G.F. Stevens, photographer for the London Photographic Studio. Might it be George F. Stevens? www.cartedevisite.co.uk/photographers-category/photograph... Yes, this fellow in 1867: www.askaboutireland.ie/aai-files/assets/libraries/cork-ci... Ah, but it appears he was out of business by 1871, as 1870 is the last edition to have his name. And here's a sample of his work. jacolette.wordpress.com/2012/02/15/2467/

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: So we're down to 1863-1870. Oh, I did some magic on the writing on the side of the building as in the tag above, see www.flickr.com/photos/66151649@N02/7974982099/in/photostream. Seems to be an Account Book, Paper Manufacturer?

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/66151649@N02] Yes, the street directories seem to agree on G.F. Stevens, he's not in the 1863 Laing's. He is in the 1867 Henry & Coughlan's and the 1870 Slater's, but not in the 1871 Fulton's.
